Its exploration of the human condition Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the ultimate message of the novel "Crime and Punishment" according to the author? Options: A. That morality is relative and subjective, B. That individualism is the key to success, C. That redemption is possible through personal sacrifice, D. That the possibility of redemption is the true nature of punishment Correct Option: D
Question 11: In the novel "Crime and Punishment", what is the significance of Raskolnikov's rationalization that his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative pawnbroker's death would be a net benefit to society? Options: A. It shows his complete disregard for human life, B. It highlights his intellectual superiority, C. It reflects the societal norms of the time, D. It demonstrates his utilitarian philosophy Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is the role of the character Marmeladov in the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. He is a wealthy and influential figure, B. He is a corrupt and exploitative pawnbroker, C. He is a miserable former official who has drank his family into ruin, D. He is a young and ambitious law student Correct Option: C
Question 13: How does the author, Dostoyevsky, portray the character of Raskolnikov in the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. As a completely evil and depraved individual, B. As a complex and multi-dimensional character with both positive and negative traits, C. As a one-dimensional character with no depth or nuance, D. As a completely innocent and virtuous individual Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the significance of the setting of the novel "Crime and Punishment" in 19th century Saint Petersburg? Options: A. It provides a romantic and idealized backdrop for the story, B. It highlights the societal and economic struggles of the time, C. It shows the beauty and grandeur of the city, D. It provides a sense of nostalgia and longing Correct Option: B

Through the character of Raskolnikov's gradual and imperfect redemption, C. Through the character of Raskolnikov's lack of redemption and continued suffering, D. Through the character of Raskolnikov's complete lack of remorse Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky 
took these questions up in what would become one of the 
best-known works of Russian literature: "Crime and Punishment." First serialized in a literary 
magazine in 1866, the novel tells the story of Rodion 
Romanovich Raskolnikov, a young law student in Saint Petersburg. Raskolnikov lives in abject poverty, and at the start of the story has run 
out of funds to continue his studies. Letters from his rural home 
only add to his distress when he realizes how much his mother and 
sister have sacrificed for his success. Increasingly desperate after selling the last of his valuables
to an elderly pawnbroker, he resolves on a plan 
to murder and rob her. But the impact of carrying out 
this unthinkable act proves to be more than 
he was prepared for. Though the novel is sometimes cited as one
of the first psychological thrillers, its scope reaches far beyond 
Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil. From dank taverns to dilapidated 
apartments and claustrophobic police stations, the underbelly of 19th century Saint 
Petersburg is brought to life by Dostoyevsky’s searing prose. We’re introduced to characters 
such as Marmeladov, a miserable former official who 
has drank his family into ruin, and Svidrigailov, an unhinged 
and lecherous nobleman. As Raskolnikov’s own family 
arrives in town, their moral innocence stands 
in stark contrast to the depravity of those around them, even as their fates grow 
increasingly intertwined. This bleak portrait of Russian society reflects the author’s own complex life 
experiences and evolving ideas. As a young writer who left behind 
a promising military career, Fyodor had been attracted to 
ideas of socialism and reform, and joined a circle of intellectuals to 
discuss radical texts banned by the Imperial government. Upon exposure, members of this group, including 
Dostoyevsky, were arrested. Many were sentenced to death, only to be subjected to a mock execution 
and last-minute pardon from the Tsar. Dostoyevsky spent the next four 
years in a Siberian labor camp before being released in 1854. The experience left him with a far 
more pessimistic view of social reform, and his focus shifted toward 
spiritual concerns. In the 1864 novella "Notes from 
Underground," he expounded on his belief that utopian
Western philosophies could never satisfy the contradictory 
yearnings of the human soul. "Crime and Punishment" was conceived 
and completed the following year, picking up on many of the same themes. In many ways, the novel follows a common 
narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and
corrupted by the dangers of urban life. But its social critique cuts far deeper. Raskolnikov rationalizes that 
his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative 
pawnbroker’s death would be a net benefit to society. In doing so, he echoes the doctrines of egoism 
and utilitarianism embraced by many of Dostoyevsky’s 
contemporary intellectuals. And in believing that his intelligence 
allows him to transcend moral taboos, Raskolnikov cuts himself off from 
his own humanity. Yet although the book is deeply 
concerned with morality, "Crime and Punishment" never comes across
as merely moralizing, with each character given their own 
distinctive and convincing voice. One of the most remarkable things about
"Crime and Punishment" is its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder 
being revealed in the first act. Raskolnikov’s crime is clear. But it’s only through Dostoyevsky’s 
gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Whom does Raskolnikov kill?
Options: A. A policeman, B. A pawnbroker, C. His father
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky 
took these questions up in what would become one of the 
best-known works of Russian literature: "Crime and Punishment." First serialized in a literary 
magazine in 1866, the novel tells the story of Rodion 
Romanovich Raskolnikov, a young law student in Saint Petersburg. Raskolnikov lives in abject poverty, and at the start of the story has run 
out of funds to continue his studies. Letters from his rural home 
only add to his distress when he realizes how much his mother and 
sister have sacrificed for his success. Increasingly desperate after selling the last of his valuables
to an elderly pawnbroker, he resolves on a plan 
to murder and rob her. But the impact of carrying out 
this unthinkable act proves to be more than 
he was prepared for. Though the novel is sometimes cited as one
of the first psychological thrillers, its scope reaches far beyond 
Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil. From dank taverns to dilapidated 
apartments and claustrophobic police stations, the underbelly of 19th century Saint 
Petersburg is brought to life by Dostoyevsky’s searing prose. We’re introduced to characters 
such as Marmeladov, a miserable former official who 
has drank his family into ruin, and Svidrigailov, an unhinged 
and lecherous nobleman. As Raskolnikov’s own family 
arrives in town, their moral innocence stands 
in stark contrast to the depravity of those around them, even as their fates grow 
increasingly intertwined. This bleak portrait of Russian society reflects the author’s own complex life 
experiences and evolving ideas. As a young writer who left behind 
a promising military career, Fyodor had been attracted to 
ideas of socialism and reform, and joined a circle of intellectuals to 
discuss radical texts banned by the Imperial government. Upon exposure, members of this group, including 
Dostoyevsky, were arrested. Many were sentenced to death, only to be subjected to a mock execution 
and last-minute pardon from the Tsar. Dostoyevsky spent the next four 
years in a Siberian labor camp before being released in 1854. The experience left him with a far 
more pessimistic view of social reform, and his focus shifted toward 
spiritual concerns. In the 1864 novella "Notes from 
Underground," he expounded on his belief that utopian
Western philosophies could never satisfy the contradictory 
yearnings of the human soul. "Crime and Punishment" was conceived 
and completed the following year, picking up on many of the same themes. In many ways, the novel follows a common 
narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and
corrupted by the dangers of urban life. But its social critique cuts far deeper. Raskolnikov rationalizes that 
his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative 
pawnbroker’s death would be a net benefit to society. In doing so, he echoes the doctrines of egoism 
and utilitarianism embraced by many of Dostoyevsky’s 
contemporary intellectuals. And in believing that his intelligence 
allows him to transcend moral taboos, Raskolnikov cuts himself off from 
his own humanity. Yet although the book is deeply 
concerned with morality, "Crime and Punishment" never comes across
as merely moralizing, with each character given their own 
distinctive and convincing voice. One of the most remarkable things about
"Crime and Punishment" is its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder 
being revealed in the first act. Raskolnikov’s crime is clear. But it’s only through Dostoyevsky’s 
gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT a character in the book?
Options: A. Marmeladov, B. Svidrigailov, C. Bezukhov
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5

**Transcript**:
What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky 
took these questions up in what would become one of the 
best-known works of Russian literature: "Crime and Punishment." First serialized in a literary 
magazine in 1866, the novel tells the story of Rodion 
Romanovich Raskolnikov, a young law student in Saint Petersburg. Raskolnikov lives in abject poverty, and at the start of the story has run 
out of funds to continue his studies. Letters from his rural home 
only add to his distress when he realizes how much his mother and 
sister have sacrificed for his success. Increasingly desperate after selling the last of his valuables
to an elderly pawnbroker, he resolves on a plan 
to murder and rob her. But the impact of carrying out 
this unthinkable act proves to be more than 
he was prepared for. Though the novel is sometimes cited as one
of the first psychological thrillers, its scope reaches far beyond 
Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil. From dank taverns to dilapidated 
apartments and claustrophobic police stations, the underbelly of 19th century Saint 
Petersburg is brought to life by Dostoyevsky’s searing prose. We’re introduced to characters

has drank his family into ruin, and Svidrigailov, an unhinged

arrives in town, their moral innocence stands

increasingly intertwined. This bleak portrait of Russian society reflects the author’s own complex life 
experiences and evolving ideas. As a young writer who left behind

ideas of socialism and reform, and joined a circle of intellectuals to

narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and

gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

Options: A. Discussing banned texts, B. Plotting to overthrow the tsar, C. Spying for the British Crown
Correct Option: A

To alleviate his poverty and fund his studies, and to rationalize that his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative pawnbroker's death would be a net benefit to society, B. To gain wealth and fame, C. To avenge a past injustice, D. To alleviate his poverty and fund his studies Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the name of the literary movement that Dostoyevsky was attracted to as a young writer? Options: A. Realism, B. Romanticism, C. Socialism and Reform, D. Utopianism Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome for Dostoyevsky and his fellow intellectuals after they were exposed for discussing radical texts banned by the Imperial government? Options: A. They were released and their careers flourished, B. They were sentenced to death, but later pardoned, C. They were imprisoned for several years, D. They were forced to flee the country Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the outcome for Dostoyevsky after being released from prison in 1854? Options: A. He became a prominent figure in Russian literature, B. He shifted his focus towards spiritual concerns, C. He lost his faith in social reform, D. He returned to his military career Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the main theme of the novel "Crime and Punishment" according to the author? Options: A. The struggle between individualism and morality, B. The dangers of urban life, C. The importance of wealth and material possessions, D. The power of love and redemption Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is a remarkable aspect of the novel "Crime and Punishment" according to the author? Options: A. Its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder being revealed in the first act, B. Its complex and multi-layered characters, C. Its critique of social reform, D. Its exploration of the human condition Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the ultimate message of the novel "Crime and Punishment" according to the author? Options: A. That morality is relative and subjective, B. That individualism is the key to success, C. That redemption is possible through personal sacrifice, D. That the possibility of redemption is the true nature of punishment Correct Option: D
Question 11: In the novel "Crime and Punishment", what is the significance of Raskolnikov's rationalization that his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative pawnbroker's death would be a net benefit to society? Options: A. It shows his complete disregard for human life, B. It highlights his intellectual superiority, C. It reflects the societal norms of the time, D. It demonstrates his utilitarian philosophy Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is the role of the character Marmeladov in the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. He is a wealthy and influential figure, B. He is a corrupt and exploitative pawnbroker, C. He is a miserable former official who has drank his family into ruin, D. He is a young and ambitious law student Correct Option: C
Question 13: How does the author, Dostoyevsky, portray the character of Raskolnikov in the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. As a completely evil and depraved individual, B. As a complex and multi-dimensional character with both positive and negative traits, C. As a one-dimensional character with no depth or nuance, D. As a completely innocent and virtuous individual Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the significance of the setting of the novel "Crime and Punishment" in 19th century Saint Petersburg? Options: A. It provides a romantic and idealized backdrop for the story, B. It highlights the societal and economic struggles of the time, C. It shows the beauty and grandeur of the city, D. It provides a sense of nostalgia and longing Correct Option: B
Question 15: How does the novel "Crime and Punishment" explore the theme of redemption? Options: A. Through the character of Raskolnikov's complete transformation and rehabilitation, B. Through the character of Raskolnikov's gradual and imperfect redemption, C. Through the character of Raskolnikov's lack of redemption and continued suffering, D. Through the character of Raskolnikov's complete lack of remorse Correct Option: B

Matching Response:

They were forced to flee the country Correct Option: B.

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it addresses the reason for Dostoyevsky's arrest and the outcome of that event. Although the ground truth MCQ specifically asks why Dostoyevsky was arrested, the correct answer to that question is closely related to the correct answer to Question 6, which is that he was arrested for discussing banned texts and was sentenced to death but later pardoned.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In a LiDAR system, what is the role of super short laser pulses?
Options: A. to resolve the width of small objects, B. to sample a distance measurement many times, C. to resolve the depth of thin objects, D. to resolve the depth of objects at great distances
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main challenge faced by a self-driving car when navigating through a country road with multiple hazards? Options: A. It needs to plot the safest course without sufficient information about the hazards., B. The car needs to detect the hazards quickly, but its sensors are not sensitive enough., C. The car needs to gather enough information about the hazards' size, shape, and position to plot the safest course., D. The car needs to make a decision without human intervention. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary difference between radar and LIDAR systems in terms of their ability to visualize details? Options: A. Radar systems use radio waves, while LIDAR systems use infrared lasers., B. Radar systems can visualize finer details than LIDAR systems., C. LIDAR systems can visualize finer details than radar systems, which are limited by their large beam-size., D. LIDAR systems are more complex than radar systems. Correct Option: C
Question 3: How does a Mach-Zehnder modulator create pulses of light? Options: A. By switching a laser on and off., B. By slowing down and delaying waves of light along two parallel arms, allowing them to recombine out of sync and cancel., C. By emitting pulses of light through a complex process., D. By using a different type of laser. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary advantage of using a Mach-Zehnder modulator in a LIDAR system? Options: A. It allows for faster scanning speeds., B. It provides more accurate depth resolution., C. It enables the creation of pulses of light with precise timing, allowing for detailed imaging of the environment., D. It reduces the complexity of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the expected resolution of a LIDAR system paired with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector? Options: A. A few centimeters., B. A millimeter., C. A few millimeters., D. A few kilometers. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary challenge faced by the first generation of automobile LIDAR systems? Options: A. Their complexity., B. Their reliance on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods., C. Their inability to scan at rapid speeds., D. Their large size and heavy size. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How do modulators and detectors in integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary advantage of using a steerable laser beam in a LIDAR system? Options: A. It enables faster scanning speeds., B. It provides more accurate depth resolution., C. It allows for the creation of a more detailed profile of the environment by probing and seeing more thoroughly., D. It reduces the complexity of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the expected outcome of pairing a modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector in a LIDAR system? Options: A. Improved scanning speeds., B. Increased depth resolution., C. Reduced complexity of the LIDAR system., D. Improved accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How do integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips that can fit inside a car's lights? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. However, upon closer inspection, it appears that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

However, if I had to choose the most similar one, I would say it's Question 9: What is the expected outcome of pairing a modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector in a LIDAR system? Options: A. Improved scanning speeds., B. Increased depth resolution., C. Reduced complexity of the LIDAR system., D. Improved accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B

This question is related to the concept of improving depth resolution in a LIDAR system, which is the main idea behind the ground truth MCQ. However, the question and options are not an exact match.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 9.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens when you switch a laser on and off rapidly?
Options: A. instability in the laser light changes its direction, B. instability in the laser pulses limits depth resolution, C. instability in the laser pulses limit size resolution, D. instability in the laser pulses limit how far they can travel
Correct Option: B

The car needs to gather enough information about the hazards' size, shape, and position to plot the safest course., D. The car needs to make a decision without human intervention. Correct Option: C

By slowing down and delaying waves of light along two parallel arms, allowing them to recombine out of sync and cancel., C. By emitting pulses of light through a complex process., D. By using a different type of laser. Correct Option: B

It enables the creation of pulses of light with precise timing, allowing for detailed imaging of the environment., D. It reduces the complexity of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the expected resolution of a LIDAR system paired with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector? Options: A. A few centimeters., B. A millimeter., C. A few millimeters., D. A few kilometers. Correct Option: B

Increased depth resolution., C. Reduced complexity of the LIDAR system., D. Improved accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How do integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips that can fit inside a car's lights? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B

To create a more accurate match, a generated MCQ with the following content would be more suitable:

Question: What happens when you switch a laser on and off rapidly?
Options: A. It increases the depth resolution, B. It limits the depth resolution due to instability in the laser pulses, C. It changes the direction of the laser light, D. It reduces the scanning speed.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does a Mach Zehnder modulator manipulate light?
Options: A. it splits a wave of light into two different optical paths and recombines them out of sync, B. it splits a wave of light into two different optical paths and recombines them with a wavelength shift, C. it splits a wave of light into two identical optical paths, D. it splits a wave of light into two identical optical paths and recombines them with a wavelength shift
Correct Option: A

Increased depth resolution., C. Reduced complexity of the LIDAR system., D. Improved accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How do integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips that can fit inside a car's lights? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about how a Mach-Zehnder modulator manipulates light. The options provided in Question 3 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (B) describing the process of slowing down and delaying waves of light along two parallel arms, allowing them to recombine out of sync and cancel.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How can integrated photonics transform a LiDAR system in a self-driving car?
Options: A. toggle the speed of light in one arm, B. resolve the depth of small objects, C. shrink the device components into a chip smaller than a millimeter, D. resolve the depth of objects at great distances
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main challenge faced by a self-driving car when navigating through a country road with multiple hazards? Options: A. It needs to plot the safest course without sufficient information about the hazards., B. The car needs to detect the hazards quickly, but its sensors are not sensitive enough., C. The car needs to gather enough information about the hazards' size, shape, and position to plot the safest course., D. The car needs to make a decision without human intervention. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary difference between radar and LIDAR systems in terms of their ability to visualize details? Options: A. Radar systems use radio waves, while LIDAR systems use infrared lasers., B. Radar systems can visualize finer details than LIDAR systems., C. LIDAR systems can visualize finer details than radar systems, which are limited by their large beam-size., D. LIDAR systems are more complex than radar systems. Correct Option: C
Question 3: How does a Mach-Zehnder modulator create pulses of light? Options: A. By switching a laser on and off., B. By slowing down and delaying waves of light along two parallel arms, allowing them to recombine out of sync and cancel., C. By emitting pulses of light through a complex process., D. By using a different type of laser. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary advantage of using a Mach-Zehnder modulator in a LIDAR system? Options: A. It allows for faster scanning speeds., B. It provides more accurate depth resolution., C. It enables the creation of pulses of light with precise timing, allowing for detailed imaging of the environment., D. It reduces the complexity of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the expected resolution of a LIDAR system paired with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector? Options: A. A few centimeters., B. A millimeter., C. A few millimeters., D. A few kilometers. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary challenge faced by the first generation of automobile LIDAR systems? Options: A. Their complexity., B. Their reliance on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods., C. Their inability to scan at rapid speeds., D. Their large size and heavy size. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How do modulators and detectors in integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary advantage of using a steerable laser beam in a LIDAR system? Options: A. It enables faster scanning speeds., B. It provides more accurate depth resolution., C. It allows for the creation of a more detailed profile of the environment by probing and seeing more thoroughly., D. It reduces the complexity of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the expected outcome of pairing a modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector in a LIDAR system? Options: A. Improved scanning speeds., B. Increased depth resolution., C. Reduced complexity of the LIDAR system., D. Improved accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How do integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips that can fit inside a car's lights? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: How do modulators and detectors in integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B

However, an even more similar question is Question 10: How do integrated photonics enable the creation of smaller LIDAR chips that can fit inside a car's lights? Options: A. By reducing the complexity of the LIDAR system., B. By shrinking the size of the modulators and detectors to less than a tenth of a millimeter., C. By increasing the speed of the LIDAR system., D. By improving the accuracy of the LIDAR system. Correct Option: B

Both of these questions convey the same idea as the ground truth MCQ, which is that integrated photonics can transform a LiDAR system by shrinking its components into smaller chips. However, Question 10 is more specific about the application of this technology in a car's lights, making it slightly more relevant to the ground truth MCQ.

**Transcript**:

at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the

or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a

up to become very large; in other places, they completely

has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one

variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator

like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: On an integrated photonics chip, what does the device for steering a laser beam have in common with a Mach-Zehnder modulator?
Options: A. both devices rely on Time of Flight, B. both devices create pulses of light, C. both devices split light into multiple optical paths, repeatedly, D. both devices slow down the speed of light
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What shape are your cells? Squishy cylinders? Jagged zig-zags? You probably don’t think much about
the bodies of these building blocks, but at the microscopic level, small 
changes can have huge consequences. And while some adaptations change 
these shapes for the better, others can spark a cascade of 
debilitating complications. This is the story of sickle-cell disease. Sickle-cell disease affects the 
red blood cells, which transport oxygen from the lungs 
to all the tissues in the body. To perform this vital task, red blood cells are filled with hemoglobin
proteins to carry oxygen molecules. These proteins float independently inside the red blood cell’s pliable, 
doughnut-like shape, keeping the cells flexible enough to accommodate even the 
tiniest of blood vessels. But in sickle cell disease, a single genetic mutation alters
the structure of hemoglobin. After releasing oxygen to tissues, these mutated proteins lock 
together into rigid rows. Rods of hemoglobin cause the cell 
to deform into a long, pointed sickle. These red blood cells are 
harder and stickier, and no longer flow smoothly through 
blood vessels. Sickled cells snag and pile up– sometimes blocking the vessel completely. This keeps oxygen from reaching
a variety of cells, causing the wide range of symptoms experienced by people 
with sickle-cell disease. Starting when they’re 
less than a year old, patients suffer from repeated episodes of
stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. The location of the clogged vessel determines the specific 
symptoms experienced. A blockage in the spleen, 
part of the immune system, puts patients at risk for 
dangerous infections. A pileup in the lungs can produce 
fevers and difficulty breathing. A clog near the eye can cause vision 
problems and retinal detachment. And if the obstructed vessels 
supply the brain the patient could even 
suffer a stroke. Worse still, sickled red blood cells 
also don’t survive very long— just 10 or 20 days, versus a 
healthy cell’s 4 months. This short lifespan means that patients live with a constantly
depleted supply of red blood cells; a condition called sickle-cell anemia. Perhaps what’s most surprising 
about this malignant mutation is that it originally evolved
as a beneficial adaptation. Researchers have been able to trace
the origins of the sickle cell mutation to regions historically ravaged 
by a tropical disease called malaria. Spread by a parasite found 
in local mosquitoes, malaria uses red blood cells as incubators to spread quickly and lethally 
through the bloodstream. However, the same structural changes
that turn red blood cells into roadblocks also make them more resistant to malaria. And if a child inherits a copy of the
mutation from only one parent, there will be just enough abnormal 
hemoglobin to make life difficult for the 
malaria parasite, while most of their red blood cells retain
their normal shape and function. In regions rife with this parasite, sickle cell mutation offered a serious 
evolutionary advantage. But as the adaptation flourished, it became clear that inheriting the 
mutation from both parents resulted in sickle-cell anemia. Today, most people with 
sickle-cell disease can trace their ancestry to a country
where malaria is endemic. And this mutation still plays a key role
in Africa, where more than 90% of malaria 
infections occur worldwide. Fortunately, as this “adaptation” thrives, our treatment for sickle cell continues 
to improve. For years, hydroxyurea was the only 
medication available to reduce the amount of sickling, blunting symptoms and 
increasing life expectancy. Bone marrow transplantations 
offer a curative measure, but these procedures are 
complicated and often inaccessible. But promising new medications 
are intervening in novel ways, like keeping oxygen bonded to 
hemoglobin to prevent sickling, or reducing the stickiness 
of sickled cells. And the ability to edit DNA has raised the possibility of enabling 
stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin. As these tools become available in the areas most affected by malaria
and sickle cell disease, we can improve the quality of life for more patients with this 
adverse adaptation.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What shape should your red blood cell be?
Options: A. A Banana, B. A Donut, C. A Sphere, D. A Teardrop
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What shape are red blood cells in a healthy individual? Options: A. Squishy cylinders, B. Doughnut-like, C. Long, pointed sickle, D. Jagged zig-zags Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of hemoglobin proteins in red blood cells? Options: A. To filter out waste products from the blood, B. To transport oxygen from the lungs to all the tissues in the body, C. To regulate the flow of blood through blood vessels, D. To carry carbon dioxide from tissues to the lungs Correct Option: B
Question 3: A patient with sickle-cell disease experiences stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. What is the likely cause of this pain? Options: A. A blockage in the spleen, B. A pileup in the lungs, C. A clog near the eye, D. A snagged and piled-up red blood cell in a blood vessel Correct Option: D
Question 4: In regions where malaria is endemic, what evolutionary advantage does the sickle cell mutation offer? Options: A. It increases the risk of malaria infection, B. It reduces the resistance of red blood cells to malaria, C. It makes life difficult for the malaria parasite, while most red blood cells retain their normal shape and function, D. It has no impact on the disease Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary difference in lifespan between healthy red blood cells and sickled red blood cells? Options: A. 1-2 months, B. 10-20 days, C. 4 months, D. 1-2 years Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a common treatment for sickle-cell disease? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Bone marrow transplantation, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a promising new medication that keeps oxygen bonded to hemoglobin to prevent sickling? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Bone marrow transplantation, C. A medication that reduces the stickiness of sickled cells, D. A medication that keeps oxygen bonded to hemoglobin Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the ability to edit DNA raise the possibility of enabling stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin? Options: A. By introducing a new gene that codes for normal hemoglobin, B. By editing the gene that codes for sickle hemoglobin, C. By increasing the production of sickle hemoglobin, D. By reducing the production of hemoglobin Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the relationship between the sickle cell mutation and the spread of malaria? Options: A. The sickle cell mutation increases the risk of malaria infection, B. The sickle cell mutation reduces the resistance of red blood cells to malaria, C. The sickle cell mutation makes life difficult for the malaria parasite, while most red blood cells retain their normal shape and function, D. There is no relationship between the sickle cell mutation and the spread of malaria Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the potential impact of new treatments for sickle cell disease on patients in areas most affected by malaria and sickle cell disease? Options: A. It will increase the risk of malaria infection, B. It will reduce the quality of life for patients with sickle cell disease, C. It will improve the quality of life for more patients with sickle cell disease, D. It will have no impact on patients with sickle cell disease Correct Option: C
Question 11: In people with sickle cell disease, what is the likely effect of inheriting the sickle cell mutation from both parents? Options: A. It increases the risk of malaria infection, B. It reduces the resistance of red blood cells to malaria, C. It leads to sickle-cell anemia, D. It has no impact on the disease Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the approximate lifespan of healthy red blood cells? Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 4 months, C. 10-20 days, D. 1-2 months Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a complication of sickle cell disease that can lead to a stroke? Options: A. A blockage in the spleen, B. A pileup in the lungs, C. A clog near the eye, D. A snagged and piled-up red blood cell in a blood vessel supplying the brain Correct Option: D
Question 14: How does the location of a clogged vessel determine the specific symptoms experienced by the patient? Options: A. By the amount of oxygen available, B. By the location of the spleen, C. By the location of the clogged vessel, D. By the type of medication used to treat the disease Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the primary function of the spleen in the context of sickle cell disease? Options: A. To filter out waste products from the blood, B. To regulate the flow of blood through blood vessels, C. To store red blood cells, D. To filter out abnormal red blood cells Correct Option: D
Question 16: What is the approximate percentage of malaria infections that occur in Africa? Options: A. 10%, B. 50%, C. 90%, D. 70% Correct Option: C
Question 17: What is the relationship between the sickle cell mutation and the risk of infections in patients with sickle cell disease? Options: A. The sickle cell mutation increases the risk of infections, B. The sickle cell mutation reduces the risk of infections, C. The sickle cell mutation has no impact on the risk of infections, D. The sickle cell mutation increases the risk of certain infections Correct Option: A
Question 18: What is the primary goal of treating sickle cell disease? Options: A. To increase the lifespan of patients with sickle cell disease, B. To reduce the frequency of pain episodes, C. To improve the quality of life for patients with sickle cell disease, D. To cure the disease Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "What shape are red blood cells in a healthy individual? Options: A. Squishy cylinders, B. Doughnut-like, C. Long, pointed sickle, D. Jagged zig-zags Correct Option: B"

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the shape of red blood cells) and options (providing various shapes as possible answers). The correct option, "doughnut-like," is also similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "a donut."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What shape are your cells? Squishy cylinders? Jagged zig-zags? You probably don’t think much about
the bodies of these building blocks, but at the microscopic level, small 
changes can have huge consequences. And while some adaptations change 
these shapes for the better, others can spark a cascade of 
debilitating complications. This is the story of sickle-cell disease. Sickle-cell disease affects the 
red blood cells, which transport oxygen from the lungs 
to all the tissues in the body. To perform this vital task, red blood cells are filled with hemoglobin
proteins to carry oxygen molecules. These proteins float independently inside the red blood cell’s pliable, 
doughnut-like shape, keeping the cells flexible enough to accommodate even the 
tiniest of blood vessels. But in sickle cell disease, a single genetic mutation alters
the structure of hemoglobin. After releasing oxygen to tissues, these mutated proteins lock 
together into rigid rows. Rods of hemoglobin cause the cell 
to deform into a long, pointed sickle. These red blood cells are 
harder and stickier, and no longer flow smoothly through 
blood vessels. Sickled cells snag and pile up– sometimes blocking the vessel completely. This keeps oxygen from reaching
a variety of cells, causing the wide range of symptoms experienced by people 
with sickle-cell disease. Starting when they’re 
less than a year old, patients suffer from repeated episodes of
stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. The location of the clogged vessel determines the specific 
symptoms experienced. A blockage in the spleen, 
part of the immune system, puts patients at risk for 
dangerous infections. A pileup in the lungs can produce 
fevers and difficulty breathing. A clog near the eye can cause vision 
problems and retinal detachment. And if the obstructed vessels 
supply the brain the patient could even 
suffer a stroke. Worse still, sickled red blood cells 
also don’t survive very long— just 10 or 20 days, versus a 
healthy cell’s 4 months. This short lifespan means that patients live with a constantly
depleted supply of red blood cells; a condition called sickle-cell anemia. Perhaps what’s most surprising 
about this malignant mutation is that it originally evolved
as a beneficial adaptation. Researchers have been able to trace
the origins of the sickle cell mutation to regions historically ravaged 
by a tropical disease called malaria. Spread by a parasite found 
in local mosquitoes, malaria uses red blood cells as incubators to spread quickly and lethally 
through the bloodstream. However, the same structural changes
that turn red blood cells into roadblocks also make them more resistant to malaria. And if a child inherits a copy of the
mutation from only one parent, there will be just enough abnormal 
hemoglobin to make life difficult for the 
malaria parasite, while most of their red blood cells retain
their normal shape and function. In regions rife with this parasite, sickle cell mutation offered a serious 
evolutionary advantage. But as the adaptation flourished, it became clear that inheriting the 
mutation from both parents resulted in sickle-cell anemia. Today, most people with 
sickle-cell disease can trace their ancestry to a country
where malaria is endemic. And this mutation still plays a key role
in Africa, where more than 90% of malaria 
infections occur worldwide. Fortunately, as this “adaptation” thrives, our treatment for sickle cell continues 
to improve. For years, hydroxyurea was the only 
medication available to reduce the amount of sickling, blunting symptoms and 
increasing life expectancy. Bone marrow transplantations 
offer a curative measure, but these procedures are 
complicated and often inaccessible. But promising new medications 
are intervening in novel ways, like keeping oxygen bonded to 
hemoglobin to prevent sickling, or reducing the stickiness 
of sickled cells. And the ability to edit DNA has raised the possibility of enabling 
stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin. As these tools become available in the areas most affected by malaria
and sickle cell disease, we can improve the quality of life for more patients with this 
adverse adaptation.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many months should your red blood cells survive?
Options: A. One, B. Two, C. Three, D. Four
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What shape are red blood cells in a healthy individual? Options: A. Squishy cylinders, B. Doughnut-like, C. Long, pointed sickle, D. Jagged zig-zags Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of hemoglobin proteins in red blood cells? Options: A. To filter out waste products from the blood, B. To transport oxygen from the lungs to all the tissues in the body, C. To regulate the flow of blood through blood vessels, D. To carry carbon dioxide from tissues to the lungs Correct Option: B
Question 3: A patient with sickle-cell disease experiences stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. What is the likely cause of this pain? Options: A. A blockage in the spleen, B. A pileup in the lungs, C. A clog near the eye, D. A snagged and piled-up red blood cell in a blood vessel Correct Option: D
Question 4: In regions where malaria is endemic, what evolutionary advantage does the sickle cell mutation offer? Options: A. It increases the risk of malaria infection, B. It reduces the resistance of red blood cells to malaria, C. It makes life difficult for the malaria parasite, while most red blood cells retain their normal shape and function, D. It has no impact on the disease Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary difference in lifespan between healthy red blood cells and sickled red blood cells? Options: A. 1-2 months, B. 10-20 days, C. 4 months, D. 1-2 years Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a common treatment for sickle-cell disease? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Bone marrow transplantation, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is a promising new medication that keeps oxygen bonded to hemoglobin to prevent sickling? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Bone marrow transplantation, C. A medication that reduces the stickiness of sickled cells, D. A medication that keeps oxygen bonded to hemoglobin Correct Option: D
Question 8: How does the ability to edit DNA raise the possibility of enabling stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin? Options: A. By introducing a new gene that codes for normal hemoglobin, B. By editing the gene that codes for sickle hemoglobin, C. By increasing the production of sickle hemoglobin, D. By reducing the production of hemoglobin Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the relationship between the sickle cell mutation and the spread of malaria? Options: A. The sickle cell mutation increases the risk of malaria infection, B. The sickle cell mutation reduces the resistance of red blood cells to malaria, C. The sickle cell mutation makes life difficult for the malaria parasite, while most red blood cells retain their normal shape and function, D. There is no relationship between the sickle cell mutation and the spread of malaria Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the potential impact of new treatments for sickle cell disease on patients in areas most affected by malaria and sickle cell disease? Options: A. It will increase the risk of malaria infection, B. It will reduce the quality of life for patients with sickle cell disease, C. It will improve the quality of life for more patients with sickle cell disease, D. It will have no impact on patients with sickle cell disease Correct Option: C
Question 11: In people with sickle cell disease, what is the likely effect of inheriting the sickle cell mutation from both parents? Options: A. It increases the risk of malaria infection, B. It reduces the resistance of red blood cells to malaria, C. It leads to sickle-cell anemia, D. It has no impact on the disease Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the approximate lifespan of healthy red blood cells? Options: A. 1-2 years, B. 4 months, C. 10-20 days, D. 1-2 months Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a complication of sickle cell disease that can lead to a stroke? Options: A. A blockage in the spleen, B. A pileup in the lungs, C. A clog near the eye, D. A snagged and piled-up red blood cell in a blood vessel supplying the brain Correct Option: D
Question 14: How does the location of a clogged vessel determine the specific symptoms experienced by the patient? Options: A. By the amount of oxygen available, B. By the location of the spleen, C. By the location of the clogged vessel, D. By the type of medication used to treat the disease Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the primary function of the spleen in the context of sickle cell disease? Options: A. To filter out waste products from the blood, B. To regulate the flow of blood through blood vessels, C. To store red blood cells, D. To filter out abnormal red blood cells Correct Option: D
Question 16: What is the approximate percentage of malaria infections that occur in Africa? Options: A. 10%, B. 50%, C. 90%, D. 70% Correct Option: C
Question 17: What is the relationship between the sickle cell mutation and the risk of infections in patients with sickle cell disease? Options: A. The sickle cell mutation increases the risk of infections, B. The sickle cell mutation reduces the risk of infections, C. The sickle cell mutation has no impact on the risk of infections, D. The sickle cell mutation increases the risk of certain infections Correct Option: A
Question 18: What is the primary goal of treating sickle cell disease? Options: A. To increase the lifespan of patients with sickle cell disease, B. To reduce the frequency of pain episodes, C. To improve the quality of life for patients with sickle cell disease, D. To cure the disease Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What shape are your cells? Squishy cylinders? Jagged zig-zags? You probably don’t think much about
the bodies of these building blocks, but at the microscopic level, small 
changes can have huge consequences. And while some adaptations change 
these shapes for the better, others can spark a cascade of 
debilitating complications. This is the story of sickle-cell disease. Sickle-cell disease affects the 
red blood cells, which transport oxygen from the lungs 
to all the tissues in the body. To perform this vital task, red blood cells are filled with hemoglobin
proteins to carry oxygen molecules. These proteins float independently inside the red blood cell’s pliable, 
doughnut-like shape, keeping the cells flexible enough to accommodate even the 
tiniest of blood vessels. But in sickle cell disease, a single genetic mutation alters
the structure of hemoglobin. After releasing oxygen to tissues, these mutated proteins lock 
together into rigid rows. Rods of hemoglobin cause the cell 
to deform into a long, pointed sickle. These red blood cells are 
harder and stickier, and no longer flow smoothly through 
blood vessels. Sickled cells snag and pile up– sometimes blocking the vessel completely. This keeps oxygen from reaching
a variety of cells, causing the wide range of symptoms experienced by people 
with sickle-cell disease. Starting when they’re 
less than a year old, patients suffer from repeated episodes of
stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. The location of the clogged vessel determines the specific 
symptoms experienced. A blockage in the spleen, 
part of the immune system, puts patients at risk for 
dangerous infections. A pileup in the lungs can produce 
fevers and difficulty breathing. A clog near the eye can cause vision 
problems and retinal detachment. And if the obstructed vessels 
supply the brain the patient could even 
suffer a stroke. Worse still, sickled red blood cells 
also don’t survive very long— just 10 or 20 days, versus a 
healthy cell’s 4 months. This short lifespan means that patients live with a constantly
depleted supply of red blood cells; a condition called sickle-cell anemia. Perhaps what’s most surprising 
about this malignant mutation is that it originally evolved
as a beneficial adaptation. Researchers have been able to trace
the origins of the sickle cell mutation to regions historically ravaged 
by a tropical disease called malaria. Spread by a parasite found 
in local mosquitoes, malaria uses red blood cells as incubators to spread quickly and lethally 
through the bloodstream. However, the same structural changes
that turn red blood cells into roadblocks also make them more resistant to malaria. And if a child inherits a copy of the
mutation from only one parent, there will be just enough abnormal 
hemoglobin to make life difficult for the 
malaria parasite, while most of their red blood cells retain
their normal shape and function. In regions rife with this parasite, sickle cell mutation offered a serious 
evolutionary advantage. But as the adaptation flourished, it became clear that inheriting the 
mutation from both parents resulted in sickle-cell anemia. Today, most people with 
sickle-cell disease can trace their ancestry to a country
where malaria is endemic. And this mutation still plays a key role
in Africa, where more than 90% of malaria 
infections occur worldwide. Fortunately, as this “adaptation” thrives, our treatment for sickle cell continues 
to improve. For years, hydroxyurea was the only 
medication available to reduce the amount of sickling, blunting symptoms and 
increasing life expectancy. Bone marrow transplantations 
offer a curative measure, but these procedures are 
complicated and often inaccessible. But promising new medications 
are intervening in novel ways, like keeping oxygen bonded to 
hemoglobin to prevent sickling, or reducing the stickiness 
of sickled cells. And the ability to edit DNA has raised the possibility of enabling 
stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin. As these tools become available in the areas most affected by malaria
and sickle cell disease, we can improve the quality of life for more patients with this 
adverse adaptation.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Having sickle cell trait reduces your risk of getting what infection?
Options: A. Flu, B. Malaria, C. Pneumonia, D. Whooping cough
Correct Option: B
